#Text=IN THE ARROYO
#Text=Senor Johnson quietly approached Estrella .
#Text=The girl had , during the struggle , gone through an aimless but frantic exhibition of terror .
#Text=Now she shrank back , her eyes staring wildly , her hands behind her , ready to flop again over the brink of hysteria .
#Text=" What are you going to do ?

#Text=And then at once , as though the personal contact of the touch had broken through the last crumb of numbness with which shock had overlaid Buck Johnson 's passions , the insanity of his rage broke out .

#Text=He twisted her violently on her face , knelt on her back , and , with the short piece of hard rope the cowboy always carries to  hog-tie " cattle , he lashed her wrists together .

column1: #Text=Then he arose panting , his square black beard rising and falling with the rise and fall of his great chest .
#Text=Estrella had screamed again and again until her face had been fairly ground into the alkali .
#Text=There she had choked and strangled and gasped and sobbed , her mind nearly unhinged with terror .
#Text=She kept appealing to him in a hoarse voice , but could get no reply , no indication that he had even heard .
#Text=This terrified her still more .
#Text=Brent Palmer cursed steadily and accurately , but the man did not seem to hear him either .
#Text=The tempest bad broken in Buck Johnson 's soul .
#Text=When he had touched Estrella he had , for the first time , realised what he had lost .
#Text=It was not the woman -- her he despised .
#Text=But the dreams !
#Text=All at once he knew what they had been to him -- he understood how completely the very substance of his life had changed in response to their slow soul-action .
#Text=The new world had been blasted -- the old no longer existed to which to return .
#Text=Buck Johnson stared at this catastrophe until his sight blurred .
#Text=Why , it was atrocious ! He had done nothing to deserve it !
#Text=Why had they not left him peaceful in his own life of cattle and the trail ?
#Text=He had been happy .
#Text=His dull eyes fell on the causes of the ruin .
#Text=And then , finally , in the understanding of how he had been tricked of his life , his happiness , his right to well-being , the whole force of the man 's anger flared .
#Text=Brent Palmer lay there cursing him artistically .
#Text=That man had done it ; that man was in his power .
#Text=He would get even .
#Text=How ?
#Text=Estrella , too , lay huddled , helpless and defenseless , at his feet .
#Text=She had done it .
#Text=He would get even . How ?
#Text=He had spoken no word .

#Text=He spoke none now , either in answer to Estrella 's appeals , becoming piteous in their craving for relief from suspense , or in response to Brent Palmer 's steady stream of insults and vituperations .
#Text=Such things were far below .
#Text=The bitterness and anger and desolation were squeezing his heart .

#Text=He remembered the silly little row of potatoes sewn in the green hide lying along the top of the adobe fence , some fresh and round , some dripping as the rawhide contracted , some black and withered and very small .
#Text=A fierce and savage light sprang into his eyes .
#Text=CHAPTER THIRTEEN
#Text=THE RAWHIDE
#Text=First of all he unhitched the horses from the buckboard and turned them loose .
#Text=Then , since he was early trained in Indian warfare , he dragged Palmer to the wagon wheel , and tied him so closely to it that he could not roll over .

#Text=For , though the bronco-buster was already so fettered that his only possible movement was of the jack-knife variety , nevertheless he might be able to hitch himself along the ground to a sharp stone , there to saw through the rope about his wrists .
#Text=Estrella , her husband held in contempt .
#Text=He merely supplemented her wrist bands by one about the ankles .
#Text=Leisurely he mounted Button and turned up the wagon trail , leaving the two .
#Text=Estrella had exhausted herself .
#Text=She was capable of nothing more in the way of emotion .
#Text=Her eyes tight closed , she inhaled in deep , trembling , long-drawn breaths , and exhaled with the name of her Maker .
#Text=Brent Palmer , on the contrary , was by no means subdued .
#Text=He had expected to be shot in cold blood .
#Text=Now he did not know what to anticipate .
#Text=His black , level brows drawn straight in defiance , he threw his curses after Johnson 's retreating figure .
#Text=The latter , however , paid no attention .
#Text=He had his purposes .
#Text=Once at the top of the arroyo he took a careful survey of the landscape , now rich with dawn .
#Text=Each excrescence on the plain his half-squinted eyes noticed , and with instant skill relegated to its proper category of soap-weed , mesquite , cactus .
#Text=At length he swung Button in an easy lope toward what looked to be a bunch of soap-weed in the middle distance .
#Text=But in a moment the cattle could be seen plainly .
#Text=Button pricked up his ears .
#Text=He knew cattle .

#Text=Now he proceeded tentatively , lifting high his little hoofs to avoid the half-seen inequalities of the ground and the ground 's growths , wondering whether he were to be called on to rope or to drive .
#Text=When the rider had approached to within a hundred feet , the cattle started .
#Text=Immediately Button understood that he was to pursue .
#Text=No rope swung above his head , so he sheered off and ran as fast as he could to cut ahead of the bunch .
#Text=But his rider with knee and rein forced him in .
#Text=After a moment , to his astonishment , he found himself running alongside a big steer .
#Text=Button had never hunted buffalo -- Buck Johnson had .
